message_1: A researcher collected the following data on the number of hours of sleep per night for a group of individuals: 6, 7, 8, 8, 9, 10, 10, 15. Calculate the median and the interquartile range (IQR) for this data set.
message_2:
First, we need to arrange the data in ascending order, which is already done: 6, 7, 8, 8, 9, 10, 10, 15.

To find the median, we need to find the middle value(s) of the data set. Since there are 8 data points (an even number), the median will be the average of the two middle values. In this case, the middle values are 8 and 9. The median is (8 + 9) / 2 = 8.5.

To find the interquartile range (IQR), we need to find the first quartile (Q1) and the third quartile (Q3) and then subtract Q1 from Q3.

Q1 is the median of the lower half of the data (not including the overall median if the data set has an odd number of values). In this case, the lower half of the data is 6, 7, 8, 8. Since there are 4 data points (an even number), the median (Q1) will be the average of the two middle values, which are 7 and 8. So, Q1 = (7 + 8) / 2 = 7.5.

Q3 is the median of the upper half of the data (not including the overall median if the data set has an odd number of values). In this case, the upper half of the data is 9, 10, 10, 15. Since there are 4 data points (an even number), the median (Q3) will be the average of the two middle values, which are 10 and 10. So, Q3 = (10 + 10) / 2 = 10.

Now, we can find the interquartile range (IQR) by subtracting Q1 from Q3: IQR = Q3 - Q1 = 10 - 7.5 = 2.5.

So, the median for this data set is 8.5, and the interquartile range (IQR) is 2.5.
